Other Information.Additional Info: Ni-TABQ exhibits dual catalytic sites (Ni-N4 and quinone) which enable effective trapping and multistep catalysis of lithium polysulfides.
Ni-TABQ shows strong interaction with S8 via its Ni-N4 center, as confirmed by DFT calculations and XPS analysis.
Ni-TABQ demonstrates the highest adsorption capacity for Li2S6 among the studied materials, attributed to its dual adsorption sites (quinone and Ni-N4).

Sieving Mechanism: Chemisorption and size exclusion based on chemical interactions

Experimental Validation.Method: DFT calculations, UV-vis spectroscopy, CV measurements, in-situ Raman spectroscopy
Experimental Validation.Performance Metrics: Low capacity decay rate of 0.198‰ over 1000 cycles at 1 C; high initial area specific capacity of 6.12 mAh cm−2 under sulfur loading of 6.8 mg cm−2

Other Information.Additional Info: Ni-TABQ interlayer is ultrathin (1.8 μm) and ultralight (0.075 mg cm−2), enabling efficient ion sieving, LiPSs adsorption, and multistep catalytic conversion.
Ni-BTA primarily interacts with lithium polysulfides via its Ni-N4 center but lacks the additional quinone site present in Ni-TABQ, resulting in lower catalytic efficiency.
Ni-BTA shows stronger binding energy for S8 compared to TABQ, attributed to the Ni-N4 center's interaction with S8.
Ni-BTA exhibits lower adsorption capacity for Li2S6 compared to Ni-TABQ due to the absence of quinone functional groups.

Sieving Mechanism: Chemisorption and size exclusion based on chemical interactions

Experimental Validation.Method: DFT calculations, UV-vis spectroscopy, CV measurements
Experimental Validation.Performance Metrics: Lower performance metrics compared to Ni-TABQ; faster capacity decay during cycling tests.

Other Information.Additional Info: Ni-BTA serves as a comparative material to highlight the advantages of dual catalytic sites in Ni-TABQ.
